filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of thirty-three of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. All take their subjects from the New Testament and have been added to the twenty Old Testament subjects published in March 2010 as “Illustrations to the Bible, c. 1780-1824,” under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings. This new group is presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
Blake executed most of these New Testament water colors c. 1800-05 for his patron Thomas Butts. The exceptions are The Whore of Babylon of 1809 and The Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins in the Yale Center for British Art, datable to c. 1825. The subjects range from the childhood of Jesus to his ascension, the later history of his parents and one of his major followers, St. Paul, and a group of eight designs based on the Book of Revelation. While the illustrations of the life of Christ are fairly conventional in their subjects, in part because of the long tradition of picturing almost every event in the Gospels, individual motifs recall designs in Blake’s illuminated books and thus offer a window on Blake’s visual interpretation of the Bible. The illustrations of Revelation complement Blake’s intense engagement with apocalyptic events and images in his own poetry.
The selection of fifty-three biblical water colors now available in the Archive will be supplemented in the future with early works, such as Abraham and Isaac, datable to c. 1780, and will continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, such as Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1805; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 26 March 1852, lot 155 (£3.11s. to Francis Turner Palgrave); given by Palgrave in July 1883 to Lady Beatrix Maud Cecil on the occasion of her marriage to William Waldegrave Palmer, 2nd Earl of Selborne; sold at her death in 1950 to Walker's Galleries; passed in January 1951 to the London dealer Thos. Agnew & Sons; sold Feb. 1951 to Captain and Mrs. Vivian Bulkeley-Johnson of the Mount Trust (The Mount, Churchill, Oxfordshire); sold Christie's, 5 June 1973, lot 42 (£23,833 to Thos. Agnew & Sons acting for Paul Mellon); given by Mellon in 1975 to the Yale Center for British Art.

desc.objtitle: The Magdalene at the Sepulchre, Object 1 (Butlin 504)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work lower right with his monogram; see the textual transcription. The mount is inscribed, not by Blake, "W. Blake del.," below the center of the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is based on John 20:11-14. Toward the top center stands Jesus, facing forward and slightly right and looking down, perhaps at Mary Magdalene. He wears a gown and has long, curly hair and a beard. A halo and aura emanate from him. A halo and aura emanate from him. His arms are at his side, but bent upward slightly. At Jesus's feet kneels Mary Magdalene wearing a gown as well as a veil over her long, curly hair. Her arms are at her side, palms down. She faces forward and left slightly, looking up at Jesus with her mouth open, possibly in surprise. Her legs are bent underneath her. On a step in front of Mary Magdalene are a cloth (perhaps Christ's discarded shroud), an urn, and a vial, bottle or jar. In the left foreground kneels a winged and gowned male angel with short, curly hair. He looks down and to the right and his arm is at his side. An aura emanates from him. In the right foreground kneels a winged and gowned female(?) angel with long, curly hair. Her right arm is bent and she looks left and down. The scene takes place in a dark, stone tomb with two steps and an open arched doorway. Jesus stands on a small stone wall behind Mary Magdalene. The night sky is visible through the doorway as are two leafy trees and other vegetation, perhaps more trees.

At Jesus's feet kneels Mary Magdalene wearing a gown as well as a veil over her long, curly hair. Her arms are at her side, palms down. She faces forward and left slightly, looking up at Jesus. Her legs are bent underneath her. Her mouth is slightly open, perhaps in surprise.
On a step in front of Mary Magdalene are a cloth (perhaps Christ's discarded shroud), an urn, and a vial, jar or bottle.
In the left foreground kneels a winged and gowned male angel with short, curly hair. He bends and looks down and to the right and his arm is at his side. An aura emanates from him.
In the right foreground kneels a winged and gowned female(?) angel with long, curly hair. Her right arm is bent and she bends and looks left and down.
The scene takes place in a dark, stone tomb with two steps and an open arched doorway. Jesus stands on a small stone wall behind Mary Magdalene. The night sky is visible through the doorway.
Two leafy trees and other vegetation, perhaps more trees, are pictured in the doorway right and left of Christ.
